Scott Sears, a lieutenant in the First Battalion Royal Gurkha Rifles and the brother-in-law of tennis star Andy Murray, has achieved a remarkable feat by becoming the youngest person to reach the South Pole solo and unsupported. At the age of 27, Sears completed a 702-mile trek through harsh Antarctic conditions, including 150mph winds and temperatures as low as -50 degrees Celsius.

The journey, which took 38 days, was filled with challenges such as navigating crevasses, some of which were riddled with danger due to the risk of falling into them. Sears, who is from east London, had to adapt by using skis to cross the ice instead of being roped to a teammate.

The most dangerous part of the journey was the initial section from Hercules Inlet where sea ice meets land. Sears experienced a particularly challenging day on Christmas Eve, just 38km (24 miles) from his destination, where he hit a wall and struggled to continue. However, he managed to push through with some food, music, and motivation, eventually reaching the South Pole on Christmas Day.

Sears' journey ended in a significant personal achievement, but also a significant contribution to the Gurkha Welfare Trust. He raised over £33,500 for the organization, which will be used to rebuild schools in Gorkha, Nepal, that were destroyed in the 2015 earthquake.

Judy Murray, Andy's mother, congratulated Sears on his achievement, while Sears himself expressed his excitement and relief at having completed the journey. He is looking forward to some well-deserved rest, including a shower and food, after spending nearly six weeks alone in a tent.

The Guinness Book of Records is yet to confirm whether Sears' feat will make it into the record books, but his accomplishment is undoubtedly a testament to his resilience, determination, and physical endurance.
answers: While many people were unwrapping gifts on Christmas Day, the brother-in-law of tennis star Andy Murray was wrapping up a 700-mile, 38-day journey through brutally cold temps and blistering winds—and, he hopes, setting a world record. Scott Sears, 27, reached the South Pole on Monday, and he says he's the youngest person ever to do so solo, though Guinness has yet to offer its final seal of approval, the BBC notes. "MERRY CHRISTMAS FROM THE SOUTH POLE! Absolutely chuffed to pieces," he wrote on his blog, where he documented his unassisted adventure, which included temperatures of minus 58 degrees and wind gusts of up to 150mph. Sears said he was so tired when he finally took a rest after his trek that he fell asleep "within about 2 minutes of my head hitting the mat." Sears, whose sister, Kim, is married to the tennis star, describes a grueling expedition with icy, crevasse-marred terrain and an isolation made worse when the "iPod poltergeist" would occasionally strike, causing his music player to stop working. He says he "truly hit a wall" on Christmas Eve, where "everything was just saying 'no more, not one more step.'" But he devoured some dried meat, juice, and chocolate and pushed through, even hanging up his stinky socks as "makeshift stockings" for Santa that night. Sears' message from Andy Murray's mom once he arrived at his destination: "Well done Scott Sears." If Guinness confirms Sears' feat, he'll be three years younger than the previous record-holder, per the Telegraph. (Prince Harry drank champagne out of a prosthetic leg when he arrived at the South Pole.)
